newsitem.title: SINGAPORE: LONDON ROBUSTAS SEEN DOWN, ASIAN TRADE IN DOLDRUMS.
newsitem.headline: LONDON ROBUSTAS SEEN DOWN, ASIAN TRADE IN DOLDRUMS.

text.p: London robusta futures are likely to open lower on Wednesday after the sharp fall in New York arabicas, regional coffee dealers said.
They said London should be US$10-$100 lower and prices were likely to fall even further.
The September robusta contract in London slid $110 to end at $1,520 a tonne. September arabicas tumbled 11.15 cents to end at 188.20 U.S. cents a lb after heavy speculative and trade selling.
"I think you can look at London coming down another $100 easily, especially after New York has done so badly," a coffee dealer in Singapore said. "I think it will drop down some more."
Other traders were more cautious.
"By the numbers, it should only be $30 lower. I'm calling it $10 lower," one said.

The Asian coffee trade, however, was very quiet although some Vietnamese exporters were said to have started making offers of a few hundred tonnes for their new crop Grade 2 coffee, 8.0 percent black and broken, dealers said.
"It's very, very, very quiet. We're in between seasons. The Indonesian harvest is almost over while people are now just waiting for the Vietnamese crop in November," a dealer said.
"I don't think anybody is doing any kind of business at the moment. There's not much happening. The physical side is very quiet," another said.
Roasters are not expected to make their winter purchases until the end of the month, dealers said.
"The roasters won't come in now. Their people are on holiday," one said.
Indonesian exporters may decide to unload some of their beans ahead of the Vietnamese harvest in November in fear that coffee prices may ease further.
"Before the Vietnamese come out, some of the Indonesians will probably sell by then," one coffee house dealer said.
Other Indonesian coffee farmers waiting for higher prices may be forced to hold onto their beans until next year if futures prices do not firm up soon.
"Those farmers who want to hang onto the beans will probably wait until March next year," a dealer said. "They don't want to take the loss."
Traders said offers were beginning to come in from Vietnam.
"The Vietnamese are starting to offer some shipments of a few hundred tonnes," a trader said.
Another dealer said the Vietnamese want "to test the market to see what kind of prices are there for new crop beans".
Many traders said they expected a bumper Vietnamese crop with no reports of disease or bad weather so far.
Dealers expected Vietnam to export a record 300,000-320,000 tonnes of robusta beans in the November/February (1997/98) season, up around 10 percent from the previous season.
"Vietnam's crop is going great. It should easily be up by 10 percent from last year," a dealer said.
-- Singapore Newsroom (65) 870-3305; Fax (65) 776-8112
-- Email: singapore.newsroom@reuters.com
